SENT.plain: Littoral cell angioma (LCA) of the spleen is a relatively recently described rare entity, which is associated with haemophagocytosis
In this case report, we will present a case of myelodysplastic syndrome with multiple LCA of the spleen
The patient presented with pancytopenia and multiple haemangiomas were observed in spleen during diagnostic abdominal ultrasound
She required a transfusion of one to two units of packed blood every 4-6 weeks and she eventually underwent a splenectomy in order to decrease the transfusion requirement
Although the patient's pancytopenia improved after surgery, the patient did not achieve a normal haemoglobin level in the two years following the splenectomy

Following further studies, bone marrow aspiration was undertaken and demonstrated minimal dysplasia in erythroid series including nuclear abnormalities, irregular cytoplasmic borders and irregular staining of the cytoplasm
The patient was diagnosed as myelodysplastic syndrome
As LCA of the spleen and myelodysplastic syndrome may both cause cytopenia their co-existence may complicate the clinical presentation leading to an incomplete or inappropriate diagnosis

In cases of haematological disorders with an atypical course, the radiological examination of the spleen should be considered and the possibility of angiomas must be included to the differential diagnosis
